Thanks Johannes,

It's pretty straightforward in its own way. I need to execute an arbitrary
set of test methods (using @test annotations) against a known -- but not yet
existent at JUnit launch time -- set of classes. Those classes are generated
and compiled in a previous test case within same session and then need to be
loaded dynamically. Ideally, I would present the name of classes as Strings;
I understand that JUnit has a way to do this dynamically for method names
but I can't find a similar feature for class names -- everything I've tried
ends up forcing me to have an explicit compiled reference at test harness
launch time.

And of course I'd really like not to have to write my own runner
implementation. ;) In TestNG I can do this with factories but our build
environment currently only supports JUnit.

Miles

On Wed, May 13, 2009 at 4:23 AM, Johannes Link <jl@...> wrote:

>
>
> I guess your own runner implementation to use with @RunWith could do the
> trick. To offer more concrete advice I need more concrete requirements ;-)
>
> Johannes
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com>, "Miles Parker"
> <milesparker@...> wrote:
> >
> > After doing a fair amount of research, I just can't seem to find a
> > viable way to test classes that are loaded during test-time. For
> > example, my use case is launching some tests from an Eclipse plugin
> > test for code-generated classes.
> >
> > This situation is actually more difficult under JUnit4 because of
> > reliance on annotations. I can't find a path that doesn't require
> > class names to exist at compile time. Am I missing something?
> >
>
>  
>
